environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Worthing CR; Pesticide Manual p. 553 (1987) (2) Kenaga EE; Ecotox Environ Safety 4: 26-38 (1980)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Based upon a water solubility of 320 ppm at 20 °C(1), a BCF of 24 has been estimated(2). Based upon this estimated BCF, methoprotryne will not be expected to bioconcentrate in aquatic organisms(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: White-Stevens, R. (ed.). Pesticides in the Environment: Volume 3. New York: Marcel Dekker, Inc., 1977., p. 90
environmental_biodegradations.Value: MOST OF THE TRIAZINES ARE VERY STABLE IN SOIL & DISSIPATE SLOWLY THROUGH ... DEGRADATION OF MOLECULAR SIDE CHAINS BY SOIL MICROORGANISMS. /TRIAZINES/

mechanism_of_action.References: Hartley, D. and H. Kidd (eds.). The Agrochemicals Handbook. Old Woking, Surrey, United Kingdom: Royal Society of Chemistry/Unwin Brothers Ltd., 1983., p. A270/Oct 83

American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists. Documentation of the Threshold Limit Values and Biological Exposure Indices. 5th ed. Cincinnati, OH: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, 1986., p. 44
mechanism_of_action.Value: ... Their chief mode of action appears to involve carbohydrate metabolism. The chlorinated s-triazines inhibit starch accumulation by blocking the prodn of sugars. Similar behavior has been shown for the methoxy & methylthio-s-triazines. It has been reported that the s-triazines affect the tricarboxylic acid cycle with activation of phospho-phenyl pyruvate-carboxylase causing the disappearance of sucrose & glyceric acid with the formation of aspartic & malic acids. /s-Triazines/

mechanism_of_action.References: Menzie, C.M. Metabolism of Pesticides. U.S. Department of the Interior, Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife, Publication 127. Washington, DC: U.S. Government Printing Office, 1969., p. 312
mechanism_of_action.Value: SINCE CHLOROSIS IS THE FIRST SIGN OF THE EFFECT OF TRIAZINES ON PLANTS, INTERFERENCE WITH CARBON DIOXIDE ASSIMILATION & SUGAR FORMATION CAN BE EXPECTED. STUDIES SHOWING THAT HILL REACTION IS INHIBITED CONFIRMED THIS. /TRIAZINES/

soil_absorption_mobility.References: Doull, J., C.D.Klassen, and M.D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 3rd ed., New York: Macmillan Co., Inc., 1986., p. 833
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: ADSORPTION OF TRIAZINES THROUGH EXCHANGE PROCESS TO ORGANIC MATTER & CLAY MINERALS IS DEPENDENT ON PH OF SOLN & ACIDITY OF ADSORBENT SURFACE. HYDROGEN BONDING & HYDROPHOBIC BONDING ARE OTHER MECHANISMS BY WHICH SOIL ORGANIC MATTER ADSORBS TRIAZINE HERBICIDES, ESP AT HIGHER PH LEVELS. ... TRANSPORT FROM SOIL TO WATER OCCURS IN SOLUTION & IN SEDIMENTS. /TRIAZINE HERBICIDES/

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Senesi N, Testini C; Geoderma 28: 129-46 (1982) (2) Senesi N, Testini C; Chemosphere 13: 461-8 (1984) (3) Worthing CR; Pesticide Manual p. 553 (1987) (4) Kenaga EE; Ecotox Environ Safety 4: 26-38 (1980) (5) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 16-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Based upon a water solubility of 320 ppm at 20 degC(3), a Koc of 180 has been estimated(4). Based upon this estimated Koc, methoprotryne will be expected to exhibit medium mobility in soil(5). Evidence has been reported which indicates that the basicity of s-triazine herbicides, such as methoprotryne, is not the main factor governing adsorption to soil humic acids(1). It has been shown that the ability of s-triazines herbicides to act as electron donors to electron acceptor quinone-like units of humic acids also plays an important role in the adsorption(2).
